The weird thing about the tippe top is that the axis of rotation actually rotates 180 degrees within itself. However, the axis of rotation does stay unchanged relative to the table top. Anyway, when the axis of rotation eventually comes back into its original line, the direction of rotation within itself is REVERSED! Obviously, it happens because of the frictional forces of the table top, and it's offset centre of gravity. And of course, the decrease in kinetic energy is equal to the increase in gravitational energy when the heaviest part is on the top. But why is it stable when the heaviest part is on the top? I'm still thinking about it. But I don't think you can explain it with gyro precession. Gyros don't change their direction of rotation! Explain that. By the way, your background music drives me mad. Working in a lab with silence is the only way for me.

Have you ever played with a rattleback? It's billed as a top that only spins one direction, and will quickly stop and reverse direction if you spin it the other way. That's probably true enough for the ones I see online, which have a highish aspect ratio (major to semimajor axis). But one of the wooden rattlebacks I made in the day had a lower aspect ratio; that one would stop and reverse direction _both ways_, sometimes as many as five times.

The rattleback is similar to your PhiTOP in that it taps angular momentum via friction, except that it converts the momentum into a lengthwise rocking motion (the rattle), and then back to rotation in the opposite direction. I read about it in Scientific American some decades ago.

I believe it was that same article that mentioned a typical class ring behaves like a tippe top. At any rate, when spun on the stone, such a ring usually flips over and continues spinning with the stone on top.

When I took a photochemistry elective, the professor ended a lecture one day with a top that would spin in one direction only.  Try to spin it in the other direction, and it would wobble then reverse.  He used it as a prompt for an open ended extra credit quetion: How does it work, and how is it relevant to photochemistry?  Totally one of the best classes I took in school.  The top he has, I found out later, is called a Rattleback and was based on a stone axhead found in a Celtic digsite in Scotland.

Halfway through the video, I started thinking about how ice-skaters spin, then bring their arms in to speed up. I paused the video, then stood up and did a quick spin to help me think it through.

I didn't think about the fact that I was just wearing socks. I was quite surprised when I actually did speed up significantly when I pulled my arms in.

So I can confirm that the ice-skater spinning trick totally works in sock feet. Also, I got really dizzy, so be careful if you try this.

It may not work with a raw egg, but there's another trick you can do with one of those. Spin it, then gently but quickly stop it by pressing down on it with your palm. If you release it soon, it will begin spinning again on its own. This is because the fluid interior never had time to stop rotating, but it can look very strange to someone not expecting it.
